Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Trait Evolution and the Stability of Ecological Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental changes, such as those associated with global climate change, can affect the stability of natural communities. These same changes may also affect how species evolve, especially on very short time scales (months to decades). The goal of this project is to understand how to measure and predict the stability of natural communities, particularly when species evolve in response to environmental changes. While ecological and evolutionary processes were traditionally not studied together, there is mounting evidence that these processes interact and affect present-day communities (i.e. eco-evo feedbacks). A fundamental challenge facing evolutionary ecologists is to determine the extent to which these eco-evo feedbacks affect species abundances and the stability of communities. This project tackles this challenge by developing a mathematical framework for analyzing eco-evo feedbacks, and applying this framework to species in a natural community. Specifically, the investigators will use pitcher plant communities to evaluate the applicability of the mathematical framework and to provide an empirical basis for extrapolating theoretical results to other natural communities. These combined theoretical and empirical efforts will provide insights into when eco-evo feedbacks stabilize or destabilize ecological communities.

Understanding eco-evo feedbacks is particularly important in ecosystems where human activities are a dominant ecological and evolutionary force. Society depends on many ecosystem services, in the form of food, medicine, and energy, which in turn depend on the stability of natural communities. In analyzing the role of eco-evo feedbacks on community stability, the project will provide a framework to better understand how ecosystems respond to anthropogenic disturbances and how to potentially minimize their impact on ecosystem services.
This project will also support multiple outreach activities to K-12 education. Particularly, the investigators on this project will continue their extensive work with the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (COSMOS) at Davis, the GK-12 program to develop Data Nuggets for use in K-12 classrooms, and continued outreach to a number of organizations aimed at promoting STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) education for young women at Davis. Undergraduate students will be supported by this project and recruiting efforts will target traditionally underrepresented groups in the sciences by interfacing with Biology Undergraduate Scholars Program (BUSP), the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP), the McNair Scholars, and the California Alliance for Minority Participation (CAMP) at Davis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecological communities consist of complex webs of interacting species. Species interactions within these communities include competition, predation, and mutualism. These interactions generate dynamical feedbacks that determine community composition (i.e. which species are able to coexist within a given geographical region) as well as determine the ability of communities to recover from disturbance (i.e. community stability). To understand how these feedbacks influence species coexistence and  community stability, theoretical ecologists develop and analyze mathematical models. Traditionally, these mathematical models have treated all individuals within a species as perfectly identical. However, individuals within a species differ in many ways including gender, body size, behavior, or physiology. This variation provides the raw material for natural selection and thus is a key focus of evolutionary theory. Until recently, evolutionary biologists and community ecologists developed theory and ran experiments without fully incorporating the other discipline. This separation stemmed from the traditional belief that ecological and evolutionary processes occur on vastly different time scales e.g. a few generations versus thousands of generations. However, recent empirical evidence suggests that feedbacks between ecological and evolutionary processes can occur on  similar time scales (e.g. a few generations) and the eﬀects of these eco-evolutionary feedbacks can be substantial. 


This project developed mathematical techniques and methods to analyze community stability and species coexistence in mathematical models accounting for eco-evolutionary feedbacks. These mathematical techniques and methods were used to analyze eco-evolutionary feedbacks in several ecological modules i.e. configurations of three to five species commonly observed in nature. For example, the intraguild predation module consists of three species: a prey species and two predator species where at least one of the predators attacks the other predator. Mathematical analysis of this ecological module revealed that evolution of the predator can facilitate coexistence of all three species when the species are unable to coexist without evolution. Other ecological modules analyzed included multiple prey species sharing a common predator (apparent competition) and multiple predator species sharing a common prey (exploitative competition). In these ecological modules, evolution of predator attack rates, prey defenses, and predator immune system were considered. The mathematical techniques and methods developed in this project were also applied to nine empirical systems to assess the role of eco-evolutionary feedbacks on community stability. This assessment revealed that eco-evolutionary feedbacks can stabilize or destabilize ecological communities depending on how fast evolution occurs and depending on which species is evolving. Collectively, these results highlight the potential importance of eco-evolutionary feedbacks on the structure and stability of ecological communities. 


The project  supported the training of 2 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students and  a postdoctoral researcher.  It also supported the development of educational material for the 4-week in residence high-school program, California State Summer School for Mathematics & Science (COSMOS), at the University of California, Davis, and several graduate student winter and summer schools.
